text:
Don’t know where to post this, but I thought about a sort of “question” to pose to the group.
Many of us are TA-ing for or have TA-Ed for psyc 300 (research methods and stats part 1 for psych majors), though I haven’t had much time to go through all of the course material, it seems to me there isn’t an open science lecture or lab.
Do you think adding one would be a good idea? If so, is it possible given how information heavy the course seems to be (for many, it’s their first research/stats course)?

elements.text: Don’t know where to post this, but I thought about a sort of “question” to pose to the group.

Many of us are TA-ing for or have TA-Ed for psyc 300 (research methods and stats part 1 for psych majors), though I haven’t had much time to go through all of the course material, it seems to me there isn’t an open science lecture or lab.
Do you think adding one would be a good idea? If so, is it possible given how information heavy the course seems to be (for many, it’s their first research/stats course)?

text: I’m obviously biased here as a PSYC 300 TA this semester lol but I think that would actually be really good! If it wasn’t 411, it wouldn’t have been until this year in my MSc that I would’ve had exposure to open science. Not every psych student is going to go on to take that course though so including open science in a graduation requirement course would be super impactful

elements.text: I’m obviously biased here as a PSYC 300 TA this semester lol but I think that would actually be really good! If it wasn’t 411, it wouldn’t have been until this year in my MSc that I would’ve had exposure to open science. Not every psych student is going to go on to take that course though so including open science in a graduation requirement course would be super impactful

text: Hmm I like the idea of proposing to add it into an undergrad course somehow, but I’m not sure if psyc 300 is the right place. As you mentioned, it already has a heavy course load, and if I understand correctly, this is most students’ first introduction to doing research, so I think it would be a bit much to also throw in all the issues science is facing and then the open science solutions. I think all the issues are easier to grasp when you have a basic idea of how science works already. I didn’t do my undergrad here, so I don’t know, but could the honours thesis course be a good place for this?

elements.text: Hmm I like the idea of proposing to add it into an undergrad course somehow, but I’m not sure if psyc 300 is the right place. As you mentioned, it already has a heavy course load, and if I understand correctly, this is most students’ first introduction to doing research, so I think it would be a bit much to also throw in all the issues science is facing and then the open science solutions. I think all the issues are easier to grasp when you have a basic idea of how science works already. I didn’t do my undergrad here, so I don’t know, but could the honours thesis course be a good place for this?

text: P.S. I’ve also been thinking of adding a session into Psyc 600b for new grad students, if there is space for it ^^

elements.text: P.S. I’ve also been thinking of adding a session into Psyc 600b for new grad students, if there is space for it ^^

text: Yeah honours would definitely be a good place for that!

elements.text: Yeah honours would definitely be a good place for that!

text: I like that idea! I would think honours students would be most likely to do research out of all psych majors anyway. Matt can speak more to this, but you do have to do a proposal and presentation and such during honours so I would think preregistering may pair well with that.

elements.text: I like that idea! I would think honours students would be most likely to do research out of all psych majors anyway. Matt can speak more to this, but you do have to do a proposal and presentation and such during honours so I would think preregistering may pair well with that.

text: Preregistration may not always be necessary for all students, like with my project where it needed to be redone with a larger sample size, but I think promoting those resources would be helpful for the students who will actually be publishing their honours theses. Encouraging them to start using these practices right out of the gate would also be very helpful for them because they’re just starting out and they can help them avoid developing all the awful habits that we pick up up when we first start research lol

elements.text: Preregistration may not always be necessary for all students, like with my project where it needed to be redone with a larger sample size, but I think promoting those resources would be helpful for the students who will actually be publishing their honours theses. Encouraging them to start using these practices right out of the gate would also be very helpful for them because they’re just starting out and they can help them avoid developing all the awful habits that we pick up up when we first start research lol

text: Yeah I think preregistration is pretty intense for a honours thesis, especially doing it with a journal likely takes a lot more time and work then honours students have. But I agree, there are many other practices/habits that are good to learn from the start, and even knowing preregistration is a thing is a good thing, even if you don’t yet use it :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yeah I think preregistration is pretty intense for a honours thesis, especially doing it with a journal likely takes a lot more time and work then honours students have. But I agree, there are many other practices/habits that are good to learn from the start, and even knowing preregistration is a thing is a good thing, even if you don’t yet use it

text:
Another question: How do folks feel about undergraduates potentially joining this group?
I'm going to be talking to my lab about a journal article this week, which involves a study that was preregistered (I'll post it on resources as a good example). Julia (my supervisor) and I are pretty enthusiastic about open science so I'll probably talk about it a bit and this group could come up in the conversation. Besides Aaron and myself, the rest of the lab is undergrad volunteers who might be interested in the group.

text:
Personally I’d be good with that, and think it fits our aim of being inclusive!

I created a channel for general discussion now so there’s a more appropriate place for these types of conversations (this channel is just for people to introduce themselves). Would you mind reposting there? :)

elements.text: Personally I’d be good with that, and think it fits our aim of being inclusive!

I created a channel for general discussion now so there’s a more appropriate place for these types of conversations (this channel is just for people to introduce themselves). Would you mind reposting there? :)

text: Yes all students are welcome! We promoted specifically towards honours students in addition to grad students, because this group is probably most relevant to them, as they are actively involved with research too, but all undergrad students are welcome!

elements.text: Yes all students are welcome! We promoted specifically towards honours students in addition to grad students, because this group is probably most relevant to them, as they are actively involved with research too, but all undergrad students are welcome!
